name: imo_2020_p1
informal_prefix: \/--Consider the convex quadrilateral $ABCD$. The point $P$ is in the interior of $ABCD$. The following ratio equalities hold: $\angle PAD : \angle PBA : \angle DPA = 1 : 2 : 3 = \angle CBP : \angle BAP : \angle BPC$. Prove that the following three lines meet in a point: the internal bisectors of angles $\angle ADP$ and $\angle PCB$ and the perpendicular bisector of segment $\overline{AB}$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--Consider the convex quadrilateral $ABCD$. The point $P$ is in the interior of $ABCD$. The following ratio equalities hold: $\angle PAD : \angle PBA : \angle DPA = 1 : 2 : 3 = \angle CBP : \angle BAP : \angle BPC$. Prove that the following three lines meet in a point: the internal bisectors of angles $\angle ADP$ and $\angle PCB$ and the perpendicular bisector of segment $\overline{AB}$.-\/
theorem imo_2020_p1:
  ∀ (A B C D P Q R Z X : Point) (AB BC CD DA DQ l CR: Line),
  (formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA) ∧
  (P.sameSide C AB) ∧ (P.sameSide A CD) ∧ (P.sameSide D BC) ∧
  (P.sameSide B DA) ∧ (B ≠ P) ∧ (A ≠ P) ∧ (C ≠ P) ∧ (D ≠ P) ∧
  (2 * (∠P : A : D : ℝ) = (∠P : B : A : ℝ)) ∧
  (3 * (∠P : A : D : ℝ) = (∠D : P : A : ℝ)) ∧
  (2 * (∠C : B : P : ℝ) = (∠C : A : P : ℝ)) ∧
  (3 * (∠C : B : P : ℝ) = (∠B : P : C : ℝ)) ∧
  (∠Q : D : A : ℝ) = (∠Q : D : P : ℝ) ∧
  (∠R : C : B : ℝ) = (∠R : C : B : ℝ) ∧
  (perpBisector A B l) ∧
  (distinctPointsOnLine D Q DQ) ∧
  (distinctPointsOnLine C R CR) →
  concurrent DQ CR l := by
goal:
∀ (A B C D P Q R Z X : Point) (AB BC CD DA DQ l CR: Line),
  (formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA) ∧
  (P.sameSide C AB) ∧ (P.sameSide A CD) ∧ (P.sameSide D BC) ∧
  (P.sameSide B DA) ∧ (B ≠ P) ∧ (A ≠ P) ∧ (C ≠ P) ∧ (D ≠ P) ∧
  (2 * (∠P : A : D : ℝ) = (∠P : B : A : ℝ)) ∧
  (3 * (∠P : A : D : ℝ) = (∠D : P : A : ℝ)) ∧
  (2 * (∠C : B : P : ℝ) = (∠C : A : P : ℝ)) ∧
  (3 * (∠C : B : P : ℝ) = (∠B : P : C : ℝ)) ∧
  (∠Q : D : A : ℝ) = (∠Q : D : P : ℝ) ∧
  (∠R : C : B : ℝ) = (∠R : C : B : ℝ) ∧
  (perpBisector A B l) ∧
  (distinctPointsOnLine D Q DQ) ∧
  (distinctPointsOnLine C R CR) →
  concurrent DQ CR l
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: Consider the convex quadrilateral $ABCD$. The point $P$ is in the interior of $ABCD$. The following ratio equalities hold: $\angle PAD : \angle PBA : \angle DPA = 1 : 2 : 3 = \angle CBP : \angle BAP : \angle BPC$. Prove that the following three lines meet in a point: the internal bisectors of angles $\angle ADP$ and $\angle PCB$ and the perpendicular bisector of segment $\overline{AB}$.

name: imo_2021_p3
informal_prefix: \/--Let $D$ be an interior point of the acute triangle $ABC$ with $AB > AC$ so that $\angle DAB= \angle CAD$. The point $E$ on the segment $AC$ satisfies $\angle ADE= \angle BCD$, the point $F$ on the segment $AB$ satisfies $\angle FDA= \angle DBC$, and the point $X$ on the line $AC$ satisfies $CX=BX$. Let $O_1$ and $O_2$ be the circumcentres of the triangles $ADC$ and $EXD$ respectively. Prove that the lines $BC$, $EF$, and $O_1 O_2$ are concurrent.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--Let $D$ be an interior point of the acute triangle $ABC$ with $AB > AC$ so that $\angle DAB= \angle CAD$. The point $E$ on the segment $AC$ satisfies $\angle ADE= \angle BCD$, the point $F$ on the segment $AB$ satisfies $\angle FDA= \angle DBC$, and the point $X$ on the line $AC$ satisfies $CX=BX$. Let $O_1$ and $O_2$ be the circumcentres of the triangles $ADC$ and $EXD$ respectively. Prove that the lines $BC$, $EF$, and $O_1 O_2$ are concurrent.-\/
theorem imo_2021_p3: ∀ (A B C D E F X O₁ O₂: Point) (AB BC CA: Line), formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
D.sameSide A BC ∧
D.sameSide C AB ∧
D.sameSide B CA ∧
|(A─B)| > |(A─C)| ∧
E.onLine AC ∧ ∠A:D:E = ∠B:C:D ∧
F.onLine AB ∧ ∠F:D:A = ∠D:B:C ∧
X.onLine AC ∧ |(C─X)| = |(B─X)| ∧
circumCentre O₁ A D C ∧ circumCentre O₂ E X D → concurrent BC EF O₁O₂ := by
goal:
(A B C D E F X O₁ O₂: Point) (AB BC CA: Line), formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
D.sameSide A BC ∧
D.sameSide C AB ∧
D.sameSide B CA ∧
|(A─B)| > |(A─C)| ∧
E.onLine AC ∧ ∠A:D:E = ∠B:C:D ∧
F.onLine AB ∧ ∠F:D:A = ∠D:B:C ∧
X.onLine AC ∧ |(C─X)| = |(B─X)| ∧
circumCentre O₁ A D C ∧ circumCentre O₂ E X D → concurrent BC EF O₁O₂
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: Let $D$ be an interior point of the acute triangle $ABC$ with $AB > AC$ so that $\angle DAB= \angle CAD$. The point $E$ on the segment $AC$ satisfies $\angle ADE= \angle BCD$, the point $F$ on the segment $AB$ satisfies $\angle FDA= \angle DBC$, and the point $X$ on the line $AC$ satisfies $CX=BX$. Let $O_1$ and $O_2$ be the circumcentres of the triangles $ADC$ and $EXD$ respectively. Prove that the lines $BC$, $EF$, and $O_1 O_2$ are concurrent.

name: imo_2021_p4
informal_prefix: \/--Let $\Gamma$ be a circle with centre $I$, and $ABCD$ a convex quadrilateral such that each of the segments $AB, BC, CD$ and $DA$ is tangent to $\Gamma$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of the triangle $AIC$. The extension of $BA$ beyond $A$ meets $\Omega$ at $X$, and the extension of $BC$ beyond $C$ meets $\Omega$ at $Z$. The extensions of $AD$ and $CD$ beyond $D$ meet $\Omega$ at $Y$ and $T$, respectively. Prove that \AD + DT + T X + XA = CD + DY + Y Z + ZC\-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--Let $\Gamma$ be a circle with centre $I$, and $ABCD$ a convex quadrilateral such that each of the segments $AB, BC, CD$ and $DA$ is tangent to $\Gamma$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of the triangle $AIC$. The extension of $BA$ beyond $A$ meets $\Omega$ at $X$, and the extension of $BC$ beyond $C$ meets $\Omega$ at $Z$. The extensions of $AD$ and $CD$ beyond $D$ meet $\Omega$ at $Y$ and $T$, respectively. Prove that \AD + DT + T X + XA = CD + DY + Y Z + ZC\-\/
theorem imo_2021_p4 : ∀ (A B C D Y T Z X : Point) (AB BC CD DA: Line) (Γ Ω: Circle), formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
tangentLine AB Γ ∧ tangentLine BC Γ ∧ tangentLine CD Γ ∧ tangentLine DA Γ ∧
circumCircle Ω A I C ∧
X.onLine AB ∧ X.onCircle Ω ∧
Z.onLine BC ∧ Z.onCircle Ω ∧
Y.onLine DA ∧ Y.onCircle Ω ∧
T.onLine CD ∧ T.onCircle Ω → |(A─D)| + |(D─T)| + |(T─X)| + |(X─A)| = |(C─D)| + |(D─Y)| + |(Y─Z)| + |(Z─C)|:= by
goal:
∀ (A B C D Y T Z X : Point) (AB BC CD DA: Line) (Γ Ω: Circle), formQuadrilateral A B C D AB BC CD DA ∧
tangentLine AB Γ ∧ tangentLine BC Γ ∧ tangentLine CD Γ ∧ tangentLine DA Γ ∧
circumCircle Ω A I C ∧
X.onLine AB ∧ X.onCircle Ω ∧
Z.onLine BC ∧ Z.onCircle Ω ∧
Y.onLine DA ∧ Y.onCircle Ω ∧
T.onLine CD ∧ T.onCircle Ω → |(A─D)| + |(D─T)| + |(T─X)| + |(X─A)| = |(C─D)| + |(D─Y)| + |(Y─Z)| + |(Z─C)|
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: Let $\Gamma$ be a circle with centre $I$, and $ABCD$ a convex quadrilateral such that each of the segments $AB, BC, CD$ and $DA$ is tangent to $\Gamma$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of the triangle $AIC$. The extension of $BA$ beyond $A$ meets $\Omega$ at $X$, and the extension of $BC$ beyond $C$ meets $\Omega$ at $Z$. The extensions of $AD$ and $CD$ beyond $D$ meet $\Omega$ at $Y$ and $T$, respectively. Prove that \AD + DT + T X + XA = CD + DY + Y Z + ZC\

name: imo_2022_p4
informal_prefix: \/--Let $ABCDE$ be a convex pentagon such that $BC = DE$. Assume that there is a point $T$ inside $ABCDE$ with $TB = TD$, $TC = TE$ and $\angle ABT = \angle TEA$. Let line $AB$ intersect lines $CD$ and $CT$ at points $P$ and $Q$, respectively. Assume that the points $P, B, A, Q$ occur on their line in that order. Let line $AE$ intersect lines $CD$ and $DT$ at points $R$ and $S$, respectively. Assume that the points $R, E, A, S$ occur on their line in that order. Prove that the points $P, S, Q, R$ lie on a circle.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--Let $ABCDE$ be a convex pentagon such that $BC = DE$. Assume that there is a point $T$ inside $ABCDE$ with $TB = TD$, $TC = TE$ and $\angle ABT = \angle TEA$. Let line $AB$ intersect lines $CD$ and $CT$ at points $P$ and $Q$, respectively. Assume that the points $P, B, A, Q$ occur on their line in that order. Let line $AE$ intersect lines $CD$ and $DT$ at points $R$ and $S$, respectively. Assume that the points $R, E, A, S$ occur on their line in that order. Prove that the points $P, S, Q, R$ lie on a circle.-\/
theorem imo_2022_p4 : ∀ (A B C D T Y T R S: Point) (AB BC CD DE EA EA CT: Line), (formPentagon A B C D E AB BC CD DE EA) ∧
|(T─B)|=|(T─D)| ∧ |(T─C)|=|(T─E)| ∧ |(T─B)|=|(T─D)| ∧ ∠A:B:T = ∠T:E:A ∧
twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CD P ∧ distinctPointsOnLine C T CT ∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CT Q ∧
between P B A ∧ between B A Q ∧
distinctPointsOnLine D T DT ∧
twoLinesIntersectAtPoint CD EA R
∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint DT EA S
∧ between R E A ∧ between E A S
→ cyclic P S Q R := by
goal:
∀ (A B C D T Y T R S: Point) (AB BC CD DE EA EA CT: Line), (formPentagon A B C D E AB BC CD DE EA) ∧
|(T─B)|=|(T─D)| ∧ |(T─C)|=|(T─E)| ∧ |(T─B)|=|(T─D)| ∧ ∠A:B:T = ∠T:E:A ∧
twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CD P ∧ distinctPointsOnLine C T CT ∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint AB CT Q ∧
between P B A ∧ between B A Q ∧
distinctPointsOnLine D T DT ∧
twoLinesIntersectAtPoint CD EA R
∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint DT EA S
∧ between R E A ∧ between E A S
→ cyclic P S Q R
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: Let $ABCDE$ be a convex pentagon such that $BC = DE$. Assume that there is a point $T$ inside $ABCDE$ with $TB = TD$, $TC = TE$ and $\angle ABT = \angle TEA$. Let line $AB$ intersect lines $CD$ and $CT$ at points $P$ and $Q$, respectively. Assume that the points $P, B, A, Q$ occur on their line in that order. Let line $AE$ intersect lines $CD$ and $DT$ at points $R$ and $S$, respectively. Assume that the points $R, E, A, S$ occur on their line in that order. Prove that the points $P, S, Q, R$ lie on a circle.

name: imo_2023_p2
informal_prefix: \/--Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with $AB < AC$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of $ABC$. Let $S$ be the midpoint of the arc $CB$ of $\Omega$ containing $A$. The perpendicular from $A$ to $BC$ meets $BS$ at $D$ and meets $\Omega$ again at $E \neq A$. The line through $D$ parallel to $BC$ meets line $BE$ at $L$. Denote the circumcircle of triangle $BDL$ by $\omega$. Let $\omega$ meet $\Omega$ again at $P \neq B$. Prove that the line tangent to $\omega$ at $P$ meets line $BS$ on the internal angle bisector of $\angle BAC$.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with $AB < AC$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of $ABC$. Let $S$ be the midpoint of the arc $CB$ of $\Omega$ containing $A$. The perpendicular from $A$ to $BC$ meets $BS$ at $D$ and meets $\Omega$ again at $E \neq A$. The line through $D$ parallel to $BC$ meets line $BE$ at $L$. Denote the circumcircle of triangle $BDL$ by $\omega$. Let $\omega$ meet $\Omega$ again at $P \neq B$. Prove that the line tangent to $\omega$ at $P$ meets line $BS$ on the internal angle bisector of $\angle BAC$.-\/
theorem imo_2023_p2 : ∀ (A B C D E S L P X: Point) (AB BC CA ADE BE DL l BS: Line) (Ω ω: Circle), formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
|(A─B)| < |(A─C)| ∧ circumCircle Ω A B C ∧
S.onCircle Ω ∧ |(S─C)| = |(S─B)| ∧ S.sameSide A BC
∧ threePointsOnLine A D E ADE ∧ perpLine ADE BC ∧
D.onLine BS ∧ E.onCircle Ω ∧ threePointsOnLine B E L BE ∧
distinctPointsOnLine D L DL ∧ ¬(BE.intersectsLine DL) ∧
circumCircle ω B D L ∧
P.onCircle Ω ∧ P.onCircle ω ∧ P ≠ B ∧
distinctPointsOnLine B S BS ∧
tangentAtPoint l ω P ∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint l BS X
 → ∠ X:A:B = ∠X:A:C := by
goal:
∀ (A B C D E S L P X: Point) (AB BC CA ADE BE DL l BS: Line) (Ω ω: Circle), formAcuteTriangle A B C AB BC CA ∧
|(A─B)| < |(A─C)| ∧ circumCircle Ω A B C ∧
S.onCircle Ω ∧ |(S─C)| = |(S─B)| ∧ S.sameSide A BC
∧ threePointsOnLine A D E ADE ∧ perpLine ADE BC ∧
D.onLine BS ∧ E.onCircle Ω ∧ threePointsOnLine B E L BE ∧
distinctPointsOnLine D L DL ∧ ¬(BE.intersectsLine DL) ∧
circumCircle ω B D L ∧
P.onCircle Ω ∧ P.onCircle ω ∧ P ≠ B ∧
distinctPointsOnLine B S BS ∧
tangentAtPoint l ω P ∧ twoLinesIntersectAtPoint l BS X
 → ∠ X:A:B = ∠X:A:C
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: Let $ABC$ be an acute-angled triangle with $AB < AC$. Let $\Omega$ be the circumcircle of $ABC$. Let $S$ be the midpoint of the arc $CB$ of $\Omega$ containing $A$. The perpendicular from $A$ to $BC$ meets $BS$ at $D$ and meets $\Omega$ again at $E \neq A$. The line through $D$ parallel to $BC$ meets line $BE$ at $L$. Denote the circumcircle of triangle $BDL$ by $\omega$. Let $\omega$ meet $\Omega$ again at $P \neq B$. Prove that the line tangent to $\omega$ at $P$ meets line $BS$ on the internal angle bisector of $\angle BAC$.

name: Elements_Prop6
informal_prefix: \/--Prove that if an triangle ABC such that \angle ABC = \angle ACB, then AB=AC.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--Prove that if an triangle ABC such that \angle ABC = \angle ACB, then AB=AC.-\/
theorem Elements_Prop6 : ∀ (a b c : Point) (AB BC AC : Line),
  formTriangle a b c AB BC AC ∧ (∠ a:b:c = ∠ a:c:b) →
  |(a─b)| = |(a─c)| :=
by
goal:
∀ (a b c : Point) (AB BC AC : Line),
  formTriangle a b c AB BC AC ∧ (∠ a:b:c = ∠ a:c:b) →
  |(a─b)| = |(a─c)|
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: Prove that if an triangle ABC such that \angle ABC = \angle ACB, then AB=AC.

name: Elements_Prop37
informal_prefix: \/--ABC, BCD are two triangles and AD is parallel to BC. C,D are on the same side of AB. Prove that the area of triangle ABC is equal to the area of triangle DBC.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--ABC, BCD are two triangles and AD is parallel to BC. C,D are on the same side of AB. Prove that the area of triangle ABC is equal to the area of triangle DBC.-\/
theorem Elements_Prop37 : ∀ (a b c d : Point) (AB BC AC BD CD AD : Line),
  formTriangle a b c AB BC AC ∧ formTriangle d b c BD BC CD ∧ distinctPointsOnLine a d AD ∧
  ¬(AD.intersectsLine BC) ∧ d.sameSide c AB →
  Triangle.area △ a:b:c = Triangle.area △ d:b:c :=
by
goal:
∀ (a b c d : Point) (AB BC AC BD CD AD : Line),
  formTriangle a b c AB BC AC ∧ formTriangle d b c BD BC CD ∧ distinctPointsOnLine a d AD ∧
  ¬(AD.intersectsLine BC) ∧ d.sameSide c AB →
  Triangle.area △ a:b:c = Triangle.area △ d:b:c
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: ABC, BCD are two triangles and AD is parallel to BC. C,D are on the same side of AB. Prove that the area of triangle ABC is equal to the area of triangle DBC.

name: UniGeo_Quadrilateral1
informal_prefix: \/--In a quadrilateral QRST, QR ⟂ RS , QT ⟂ ST , and ∠ QSR = ∠ SQT.  Prove that ST = QR.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--In a quadrilateral QRST, QR ⟂ RS , QT ⟂ ST , and ∠ QSR = ∠ SQT.  Prove that ST = QR.-\/
theorem UniGeo_Quadrilateral1 : ∀ (Q R S T : Point) (QR ST RS QT QS : Line),
  formQuadrilateral Q R T S QR ST QT RS ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine Q S QS ∧
  ∠ Q:R:S = ∟ ∧
  ∠ Q:T:S = ∟ ∧
  ∠ Q:S:R = ∠ S:Q:T →
  |(S─T)| = |(Q─R)| := by
goal:
∀ (Q R S T : Point) (QR ST RS QT QS : Line),
  formQuadrilateral Q R T S QR ST QT RS ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine Q S QS ∧
  ∠ Q:R:S = ∟ ∧
  ∠ Q:T:S = ∟ ∧
  ∠ Q:S:R = ∠ S:Q:T →
  |(S─T)| = |(Q─R)|
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: In a quadrilateral QRST, QR ⟂ RS , QT ⟂ ST , and ∠ QSR = ∠ SQT.  Prove that ST = QR.

name: UniGeo_Similarity20
informal_prefix: \/--In triangle HIF, HI ⟂ FI. Given GI ⟂ FH and G is on the line HF, prove that △ F H I ~ △ I H G.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--In triangle HIF, HI ⟂ FI. Given GI ⟂ FH and G is on the line HF, prove that △ F H I ~ △ I H G.-\/
theorem UniGeo_Similarity20 : ∀ (F G H I : Point) (FH FI HI GI : Line),
  formTriangle F G I FH GI FI ∧
  formTriangle G H I FH HI GI ∧
  between F G H ∧
  ∠ F:G:I = ∟ ∧ ∠ I:G:H = ∟ ∧
  ∠ H:I:F = ∟ →
  (△ F:H:I).similar (△ I:H:G) :=
by
goal:
∀ (F G H I : Point) (FH FI HI GI : Line),
  formTriangle F G I FH GI FI ∧
  formTriangle G H I FH HI GI ∧
  between F G H ∧
  ∠ F:G:I = ∟ ∧ ∠ I:G:H = ∟ ∧
  ∠ H:I:F = ∟ →
  (△ F:H:I).similar (△ I:H:G)
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: In triangle HIF, HI ⟂ FI. Given GI ⟂ FH and G is on the line HF, prove that △ F H I ~ △ I H G.

name: UniGeo_Triangle3
informal_prefix: \/--In a triangle HIJ, HI = HJ. K is a point on segment IJ such that \angle IHK = \angle JHK. Prove that \angle HKI = \angle HKJ.-\/
formal_statement:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre

\/--In a triangle HIJ, HI = HJ. K is a point on segment IJ such that \angle IHK = \angle JHK. Prove that \angle HKI = \angle HKJ.-\/
theorem UniGeo_Triangle3 : ∀ (H I J K : Point) (HI IJ JH HK : Line),
  formTriangle H I J HI IJ JH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine H K HK ∧
  IJ.intersectsLine HK ∧ K.onLine IJ ∧ between I K J ∧
  ∠ I:H:K = ∠ J:H:K ∧
  |(H─I)| = |(H─J)| →
  ∠ H:K:I = ∠ H:K:J :=
by
goal:
∀ (H I J K : Point) (HI IJ JH HK : Line),
  formTriangle H I J HI IJ JH ∧
  distinctPointsOnLine H K HK ∧
  IJ.intersectsLine HK ∧ K.onLine IJ ∧ between I K J ∧
  ∠ I:H:K = ∠ J:H:K ∧
  |(H─I)| = |(H─J)| →
  ∠ H:K:I = ∠ H:K:J
header:
import SystemE
import UniGeo.Relations
import UniGeo.Abbre
natural_language: In a triangle HIJ, HI = HJ. K is a point on segment IJ such that \angle IHK = \angle JHK. Prove that \angle HKI = \angle HKJ.
